name: User Research
description: User Research across these episodes is about building an accurate, decision-driving understanding of customers: what triggers their behavior, what “progress” they’re trying to make, and how products fit into their real-world context. It addresses how to find and interpret high-signal qualitative and quantitative evidence (especially early), how to avoid solution-first/vanity research, and how to operationalize customer insight into product, design, growth, and go-to-market decisions—because most product failure modes trace back to weak or misused customer understanding.
subtopics: Finding true demand: uncovering struggling moments, triggers, and the real competitive set (what customers would do instead)
Turning conversations into decisions: research that changes roadmaps, prioritization, and strategy vs. “customer-obsession theater”
Early-stage learning loops: founder-led discovery/sales, tight experiment cycles, and co-creating with early customers
Customer-journey mapping beyond funnels: pre-awareness/problem stage, activation, retention, and expansion from the customer’s perspective
Operationalizing voice-of-customer: feedback loops, synthesis systems, and scaling insights via product ops and automation/AI
Measuring what matters: combining qualitative narratives with customer-perspective metrics to validate PMF and guide iteration
common_frameworks: Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD): progress, context, hire/fire, struggling moments, demand-side lens
Customer narrative interviewing / timeline reconstruction (story-based discovery over pain/gain checklists)
Customer journey mapping end-to-end (including pre-awareness and post-acquisition growth)
Evidence-guided product development (lightweight experiments, clear hypotheses, decision criteria)
Customer co-creation with early adopters (design partners / small set of deep customer collaborations)
Voice-of-Customer (VoC) systems and product-ops-led insight synthesis (feedback loops, centralized + field signals)
